The last sub-part of the first section is ten chapters that cover off on various tales in history (including free energy, N-Rays, and pyramid schemes). What I really liked about this section is that the author makes the point that it is just not 'quacks', 'scammers', and 'idiots' (the labels are mine) that fall for scams; it can also be experienced and intelligent people, everyone needs to be wary of being effected by the core principles raised in this section. ---Section 2, 3, 4---The last four sections of the book are much smaller then the first half and covers various specific cases in detail. These include ghost hunting, fake news, false balance, and naturopathy.

As The Endarkenment settles in around us, the Novella and co. book almost feels like contraband. The book itself fairly straightforwardly takes you through the basics of the lost art of not believing everything you read in the comments section of YouTube as well as the forgotten strategy of just telling the truth about stuff. In a world of Deepfakes and scripted and heavily edited reality television starring actors who appear on such shows for a living, the book appeals to pro'lly about however many science PhD's the U.S. still produces. However, these folks will find comfort in the knowledge oases of clarity still exist in the general sea of male enhancement pills made of recycled Chinese newspapers and celebrities with medical theories that are, literally, getting children killed. The writing sounds just like an over-excited geek finally getting a chance to get a word in edgewise amongst the caterwauling of as people who follow Stephen Colbert's technique of: "I think it, I say it and you read it. Sometimes I don't even think it." The style can be a little much at times and it does aim higher on the education scale but, generally speaking, the voice is clear. In short, this one light of rationality will do little to illuminate the claustrophic darkness we find ourselves in, but at least it exists and you should read it.

The book is truly what it is advertised as on the cover, a great guide through a world of bullshit. The first, and lengthiest part of the book is a guide in the most literal way. It gives tips on how to think critically and sceptically. Pitfalls to avoid, and a healthy dose of self reflection. It uses real world examples of course, but the main focus is on the actual thinking errors that occurred rather than the specific claims. As the book calls it it is filling our sceptical utility belts with the tools we need. After this the book goes over many examples of where this went wrong, some are tragic, some are hilarious, but the people making these mistakes are still human, and treated as such. Whether it is ghost hunters, 9/11 truthers, or even people who killed their adoptive daughter through less than scientific medical treatments, they all fell for basic thinking mistakes that we can all fall prey to. Even one of the coauthors fell for 9/11 truthers for a short time. I loved this book, having listened to all the episodes of the podcast a lot of it felt repetitive, but having a single source for all of it will be very handy indeed. I would prefer to have more stories of the sceptical adventure kind, but I understand the need to build a basis for new readers and old readers alike. So my hope is that there will be a sequel with more stories, because as any sceptic knows, the world is full of true believers and their unsinkable rubber duckies. On a sadder note, the dedication did get to me a little, so in that spirit thank you Perry, Steve, Bob, Jay, Evan & Cara, all sceptics and wonderful people "of some note".

This book is kind of a distilled version of 100-200 episodes of the podcast, The Skeptics' Guide to the Universe. The book does a walk through of common pseudosciences and logical fallacies which is fine, but again, this is not content that you won't pick up listening to their show. Additionally, this is a case where we're dealing with a world of fake news and return of populist fascism, I'm less concerned about people being into certain pseudosciences. I get that it's important to fight over facts and such, but the actual "how to" section is lacking. There's really no way to accelerate the long slow process of having someone build trust in you and then slowly having them realize they may be mistaken. What's even more concerning is that there is amazing advice that's been given out during the show that didn't make it into the book which almost makes me want to un-recommend the book.I got it because I was a fan. If you're familiar with the show, you don't need it. If you're not familiar with the show, listen to a few, and if you don't want to go through the back catalog but kind of like it, grab this instead.This book is likely also useful to kids or teens who may not have much a skeptical toolbox to start and it's much more inviting than Carl Sagan's The Demon-Haunted World which is much less approachable than this book.

As a long time Skeptics' Guide to the Universe podcast listener and fan, I had very high expectations for this book. I wanted a comprehensive compendium of skeptic / critical thinking basics yet something that would still expand my knowledge after years of following the podcast. And this book delivers 200% and is much much more that I have ever hoped for. Steven's and other rogues ease of explaining science and philosophical terms paired with geeky sense of humour (Star Wars, Star Trek, Lord of the Rings etc. references here and there) makes it an absolutely fantastic read from cover to cover. The skeptical concepts are neatly organised into well portioned chapters and help reader follow critical thinking narratives from start to practical implementation. This book should be read by EVERYONE, should be part of a standard school or college curriculum all over the world. It's a book I will keep going back to for years to keep myself in check on critical approach to the world.In Steve's own words "This is not a f***ing self-help book" but when applied it will change your life and world view for the better.

An excellent book on all sorts of scams to entice people into believing fake news. I gave it 5 stars because it affirmed my belief about memoirs and how accurate they are, or in most cases, are not. I quote from very early in the book, page 9 to be exact - "But how reliable is human memory? Think of a vivid childhood remembrance, the kind of memory that you recall often and that represents an important part of your history and identity. I hate to break this to you (actually, or I don't), but that memory is probably mostly, or even entirely, fake." Yes, our brains process information in such a way that what we think years later is how something happened could be the exact opposite of what we think happened. It is not just Facebook entries, or news pundits, or network news (although it is all of these things), but our own mental powers are sometimes powerless in extracting the truth from what we think is the truth. It can even be someone else's truth. This is a must-read book that helps us understand and work with out faulty circuits, and give reading memoirs a wide berth in actually taking their contents to heart.

Marilyn vos Savant was a smart woman. With a IQ of 228, she was (way) smarter than I am.No wonder she had solved the Monty Hall problem (better than I did).Where have I failed? And why?In my case it was more laziness than sheer stupidity. Later compounded by pride (weakness).What about the flat earth theory? No, I don't believe and never had that the earth is flat. Such a ridiculous proposition and one so easily falsified. Disproving it is an empty, meritless exercise.But why is it believed? Why are so many people ready and willing to believe?It is not a hard question to answer (perhaps not fully) and the matter is more substantive today than the earth flatness.Imaginary friends? Jebus anyone? Easily disproved. It's not their existence the issue, it's why the belief.ESP? It's not cognitive bias that drives the belief, or one of the many named fallacies. ESP is yet another ridiculous proposition, but where is the immense force behind the conviction coming from?I haven't (yet) finished the book, but it seems Mr. Novella is not going to provide answers, he's not even going to look at these things.

Great guide to critical thinking, it really acts as a manual, organized by topics and subsections. First the book explores ways in which we fool ourselves and how to be wary of them, then applies the knowledge with stories from the authors (IMO a slightly boring bit). The third part is about skepticism in the media, IMO one of the most interesting to understand how longer than expected the path a piece of information has to travel before being consumed, and how incentives along the way can distort the message that is ultimately delivered (I find this important because for many people this is a reason to “distrust” science in its “ever changing findings”). Part 4 includes cautionary tales on the danger of pseudoscience and how such beliefs are far from harmless (as some proponents want people to believe). The last part brings everything home, giving a summary on how to apply the skills learned on the journey to ourselves, and on how to communicate with others around controversial topics. Highly recommended.

I taught Women's Studies for over 30 years. One time I had a heated discussion with a colleague who claimed that she considered herself a prophet and she wanted her students to "convert" to feminism. I argued that I did not want conversion. I wanted to teach my students the critical thinking skills to analyze the sources and effects of sexism, racism and other forms of oppression so that they could make their own assessments and conclusions. This book presents the tools for critical and scientific thinking and problem-solving. I appreciated the authors' simple (not simplistic) and clear descriptions (except for the section on probability which I've always had trouble with) and analysis of how to approach questions and new information. I didn't always agree with everything they said but I learned quite a bit about scientific methods and how the brain functions to help enlighten or delude us. I would recommend this book for all people who are curious or perplexed about how people frequently come to beliefs that don't seem to make sense or further their own interests.

Very good. The SGU is my favorite podcast, so not surprising, but I very much enjoyed this book. I'm familiar with most of the content, but it was still very well delivered. I found myself more engrossed in this book than the fiction I've been reading recently, which is a high bar that non-fiction usually cannot get over.Everyone should be familiar with the concepts in this book, so everyone should read it. If you're not currently a skeptic, or you find some of the positions of skeptics problematic you still should be familiar with what skepticism is, so you can fairly evaluate it. This book teaches a lot about the process of thinking, and how it can go wrong, so it's useful for everyone, beyond just individual issues that people normally get hyper focused on. Similarly to the idea that if you learn to learn you'll be better than off than if you learn to memorize specific information, if you learn to think, you'll be better off than if you settle into you positions on various individual topics.Read it.

I've been a listener of the SGU Podcast for about a year and really enjoy their content, so when I saw that they had a book coming out, I had to read it. This book isn't quite what I'd expected, but was a pleasant surprise regardless. The first half or so of the book focuses not on science per se but rather logic, psychology, and fallacies in debate. I was about 20 pages in and was already thinking, "Holy crap, how to humans function AT ALL?!" But it was fascinating to learn about all of the different ways humans use mental short cuts and irrational thinking to function. Then the book gets into pseudoscience and the various ways that have cropped up over the years and continue in various forms, plus some personal experiences dealing with pseudoscience. All in all, a very interesting read and recommended for anyone interested in science, politics, sociology, psychology, debate, and history.

Dr. Steven Novella is one of the smartest persons I know of, and he is smart because he assumes that he is not.What you should always remind yourself is that the person most likely to fool you is yourself. Because of that you need to use a ton of logical tools to help yourself see through all the ways that you are likely to be wrong, whether it be through wishful thinking, logical fallacies, anecdotes or other things.This book is an excellent starting point to understand how skepticism works and why it is so important. It takes you through all the major sources of misconceptions, biases and other things that are constantly trying to mislead you.The book is entertaining, at times easy to read, but when necessary it does not hesitate to get into the finer details. If you are new to skepticism you may need to read these parts more than once to fully grasp them, and in that respect it also works as a encyclopedia that you'll want to return to again and again.

I’m planning on getting this book for many loved one’s birthdays this year. From advice on how to tell which media sources to trust, to lining out logical fallacies and how to detect them (in ourselves as well as others), to talking about, in depth, the most common subjects of pseudoscience today, I found this book very enlightening and exciting to read- I’ve highlighted, bookmarked, and taken notes throughout and plan on referencing back to it often. I gave this 4 stars due to the preachy tone in the chapter about GMO’s, the last several chapters of the book being kind of “meh” (in my opinion), and the brief part where the author comes across as an apologist for one of Hilary Clinton’s many big fat tall tales. Other than that, I highly recommend this book to literally everyone. I think our society would become more honest and less perpetually outraged by putting all of the themes in this book into practice.

As a someone who is already a skeptic and critical thinker, I didn't get much out of this book. Novella ascribes to scientific skepticism, so science is the measure of all things for him. I find this problematic because, as even Novella admits, it's difficult to distinguish legitimate science from pseudoscience. He has a long chapter on logical fallacies, but commits many himself, particularly appeal to authority. He makes a lot of "science says", "studies show", and "the consensus of scientists is" style statements throughout the book. Science, or more accurately the scientific method, is a process of continual discovery. It is dynamic, not static, and anyone claiming that the “science is established” is unscientific. Novella agrees and says this throughout the book, but it feels like he’s just paying lip service as his faith in science far outweighs his skepticism of it. However, he concludes the book by telling us not to trust him, which is the best advice a skeptic can give.

This should be required reading in every high school. A guide to how we can determine what is real from what is probably not. It really is a book on critical thinking and how to evaluate anything outside of emotionally responding. How to think, not what to think.It's going to be scoffed at by overly religious folks, or those that peddle in woo, but that really is showing it's points in real-life, that those that simply believe what they are told without strong evidence or significantly statistical relevance to any argument should not be relied upon, for anything, let alone important life decisions. It's probably not going to change climate science deniers, anti-vaxers, or young earth intelligent designers minds. But it might just make them understand why those that apply just a little critical thinking dismiss them so readily. But maybe, just maybe, those that have doubts about their strong held beliefs may begin, and have the courage to start asking questions.

A very thorough and entertaining book outlining a world view based on scientific, empirically based observations. This was not so much a "case by case" repudiation of what we might call "woo-woo" stuff (UFO's, holistic healing, conspiracy theories, etc) as much as a set of guidelines in spotting misinformation and fallacies (though it does tackle and take down many specific "fantastical" claims). It was not as "anti-religious" as I thought it might be - the author seems to have a particular interest in exposing homeopathy, but never really addresses "faith healing" - and is careful to leave most matters of spirituality out, other than to explain that by definition spiritual beliefs should not and cannot be substituted for scientific reasoning. A bit redundant at times, and sometimes a little heavy (but necessarily so) in its citing of psychological and medical research, but nonetheless a great read and a very fascinating and important book for our times.

This book contains some unexpected, interesting ideas, like the opening quote:"There is a theory which states that if ever anyone discovers exactly what the Universe is for and why it is here, it will instantly disappear and be replaced by something even more bizarre and inexplicable. There is another which states that this has already happened."Or:"Our real-time experience of the world is fleeting. The moment after we experience something, it becomes a memory.Everything we personally know about the world is memory.""Our memories serve more to support our beliefs than to inform them. In a way, they are an evolving story we tell ourselves."It looks like this book has a lot of boring fillers, but some pretty good gems in between.

A sort of hyper-rational guide to the world. A good book to gift to a friend or family member who believes in psychics, or ghosts, or auras, or the supernatural. This book will bust all their myths. More importantly: it gives one a way of thinking or an approach to understanding various unexplained phenomena.Some arguments are repeated over and over and over again. Are we, the readers of the book, stupid? Also, his brief mention of Thomas S. Kuhn's "The Structure of Scientific Revolutions" was too brief and dismissive. That book brought into the world a phenomenal change to how philosophers viewed the progress of knowledge and was an important landmark -- definitely in the league of Popper and Wittgenstein. Novella does a huge disfavor to readers by dismissing the main ideas contained in it.

This is a great guide to the many ways in which we practice and believe in faulty logic with the intent of preventing us from believing in the unproven. The Guide also provides an overview of how science is practiced, where scientists build on previous learnings, rigorously test theories, and publish their findings to enable others to replicate and confirm or disprove hypotheses. The scientific process is in contrast to pseudoscience where people use faulty logic, cherry picked results, or simple fabrication based on a desire to promote a point of view.In today's world, this guide is important if we are to escape the negative consequences associated with unscientific positions related to climate change, vaccination efficacy, and genetically modified foods, to name a few.Highly recommended.

The insights you will gain from this book (and the SGU podcast) will surely affect the way you think in a fundamental way. The authors are truly a unique voice in the skeptical movement. Somehow, they collectively reverberate the intricate and sometimes-concealed undertones of what it means to be scientifically skeptical, from the fun wittiness of it to the sheer urgency of it. The book shines relatable themes of evidence-based light on how our brains work and how those workings inevitably connect with the psychological, philosophical, socio-political, and so-many-other underpinnings of how we structure and interact with the world. This book will undoubtedly give you the tools necessary to assess and appreciate life in a more honest, truthful way.

I really liked this book, but perhaps partly because it fit with MY confirmation bias. I like to be skeptical, but I also know that it's really easy to fall into personal biases without even trying (or recognizing).The review of different kinds of logical fallacies was good, although I was already familiar with most of them, there being pointed out and given examples within the book was instructive. The fact that the author pointed out things to look for and be aware of was also enlightening. And on the one hand, it really was good to read what I believe and realize the dangers of, it was also good to be reminded of how easy it is to just believe what you want or already do without doing the requisite research!

We are bombarded by fake information everywhere we look. This book lays out exactly how to identify and debunk bullshit. It will not make you fun at parties, however. This book gave me the tools to piss off just about everyone I know. And they don’t even tackle the god question. From chiropractors, to flat earthers, to anti-vaxxers, to ghosts, they point out just how much fake is out there and how to get around it. This is, in my opinion, one of the most important books to read today. It can help you see not only your own cognitive biases, but recognize the biases in other people. The authors also have ongoing podcasts and blogs to combat every new piece of bullshit that emerges today, mostly emerging on the internet. As you can imagine, they keep very busy.

I've never listened to the SGU podcast, so this was my first introduction to their world. This book is a very nice primer on skepticism (a new concept to me), science, and logical thinking (an area where I'm well-versed). Overall it was very well-written and informative. This was a great introduction to skepticism. One tiny critique would be the chapter on logical fallacies, namely that it was a chapter with lots of concepts mushed together and no chance to practice them. Identifying logical fallacies is crucial to the kind of thinking discussed in this book, so it's a shame we didn't get a more in-depth look or at least a few practice exercises. Either way, I still recommend this one!

As soon as I found out that one of my favorite podcasts was publishing a book, I bought it immediately. You can say that I have a positive bias for this kind of material.Unsurprisingly, I loved it and if I had my way, everyone would read this. It is altogether humbling, yet empowering and liberating. If you're a skeptic already, hurry up and read this because you'll find how much more you have to learn. If you're not a skeptic, read it still and be charitable. It might be hard to stomach if you believe one of the mentioned pseudosciences, but don't let that steer you away from improving how to think about your beliefs and others.Recommended for those who refuse to watch movie trailers.

I would say this is a good general overview of many concepts to do with skepticism. I think it is just a starting point though and could have been much more thorough but that would make it too long.Perhaps in the future there could be separate editions for each topic.I would have liked to see more coverage about media bias and fake news but I did learn a fair amount and plan to research more about that topic.The sections on pseudoscience (especially dealing with medical treatments) were very sobering and reinforced a general belief: Just go for mainstream science and forget the quackery.I haven't listened to any of the podcasts yet, but hope to get to them as well.

This book has so impressed me that I will be buying a hardcopy version. Novella has the background and the credibility to serve up THE manual for anyone to learn how to identify and navigate these times of half-truths, opinions and flat-out lies. Shysters, Grifters, con-men and would-be Tyrants are not unique to these contemporary times but the capabilities and opportunities to influence people due to the technology that is available makes the influence peddlers more effective, more invasive, than ever before. Facts, proof and science matter, that's the bottom line. The objective truth can be determined and proven. I'm not going to recommend anyone reading it. However, I would urge everyone to go buy it and to know it.

Really good summary of a lot of topics around the broader subject of why people believe wrong things, from errors of perception or memory, common reasoning problems, etc. Nothing super new to me, but these have been hobby topics for years, still good to have it all in one place.My only problem was that it was hard to tell the voice behind some chapters that were clearly by the other authors. They even address this in the closing interviews on the audiobook, purposefully rewrote some of it to sound like it was all Novella's work. Um, no, you missed a couple spots, and so badly that it was actively confusing to me.

An excellent resource. Having listened to the podcast for more than ten years, I've heard all of these points before, but having it all collected, organised, and focused means the message hits much harder. What I found most helpful were the frequent reminders that all of the methods of self-deception apply just as strongly to all of us. The idea of learning all the logical fallacies so that you can make someone look stupid and win an argument is not appealing to me, but interrogating my own thinking and catching myself taking shortcuts is. The takeaway is not a feeling of superiority but of humility.

The SGU is a nicely written and information-packed introduction to the topics typically talked about in skeptic circles. With about 470 pages of information and references, it is quite hefty, but it's broken down into digestible chapters (the perfect guide to frequent bathroom breaks caused by indigestion). The last chapter, Being Skeptical, is the most important and is handled in a serious yet heartfelt manner. We are all susceptible to mistakes in our thinking and arguments, and we should take time to make the concerted effort of remembering our own mistakes while pointing out those made by others.

Interesting. I didn't like some of the points the authors make, but I have no choice but to reflect upon them. Some of the concepts that they mention are not new (Predictably Irrational by Steve Ariely had already educated me on some of the topics) even if the examples are original. They don't really get into the existence of God (simply not scientific), which is good. They made me mad sometimes (something they think is good) and shocked me into seeing positions that I don't agree with (even if, mostly, I hold the same opinions on many of the concepts). Has it changed my mind on my previous opinions? No. Do I want to send this to my Dad to convince him that man has gone to the Moon? Yes.

Amazing book!!This book is very well-written and clear. It's strength is the attention to detail. It is a must-have book if you want to get into the nitty-gritty of skeptical topics such as the fallibility of the human mind, biases, pseudoscience, and science. While you may not be interested in each and every chapter, it is meant to be more of a reference book that leaves nothing out, so this was going to be the case. Useful book to share with family and friends who want to understand as well! I found it really useful to reinforce many subjects which i had been learning about from the Skeptics Guide podcast. Looks great on my shelf next to Cosmos.

As an SGU devotee, I could hear Steve’s voice while reading this well-constructed book. Highly recommended for anyone interested in understanding the logic behind pseudoscience and its purveyors, and how their logical fallacies are a part of us all. The book was more a Logic Log, as intended, than an engaging read, and I found myself wanting more details for many of the examples. But the book would have been ridiculously long, so its current size is a reasonable accommodation. Well worth the time and price - and nice to be able to read it in bits and pieces as I await the next SGU podcast drop!

Although Novella sometimes wades too far into the weeds and can't resist getting into overly complex scientific details, this remains an indispensable guide to skepticism and critical thinking. The world would be a much better place if everyone read it and truly made an effort to question why they believe what they do. It is full of excellent and compelling stories of the harm magical belief and pseudoscience cause and models the skills a skeptical thinker needs - not least of which is questioning ones own beliefs and being willing to change an opinion based on new evidence.

I got my copy signed at New York comic Con this year and was super excited to read it. I'll admit the first 250 pages are a little dry but the information is good and I found the last 200 pages or so fascinating. This book makes many good points, it's more of an outline of pop culture issue science faces today. I don't think this book will change anyone's mind I think it's geared more to people who agree with these ideas, being someone who does I found this book very enlightening. I gave me a few things to think about especially in the way I will approach science denialist in the future.

I've been reading science and skeptical blogs for over a decade, so most of this wasn't new to me, but it was a well put together book. The bulk of the book is about concepts and how to think: confirmation bias, logical fallacies, the availability heuristic, and so on. The section about specific adventures in skepticism is shorter, but fun--nothing new. It's a good read for sharpening up your thinking, though occasionally it could do with acknowledging some of science's weaknesses--not so much the concept of scientific investigation, but the limits of our scientific knowledge.

Written as an updated version of Carl Sagan's "The Demon-Haunted World: Science as a Candle in the Dark", the book succeeds. Steven Novella discusses not just basic logical fallacies we as humans often use (and fall for), but also how our brains work, and how our memories might not be what they seem, and why this allows us to hold irrational or nonsensical beliefs.This book should be mandatory for everyone. Critical thinking skills are sorely lacking in a world that follows "fake news" more than ever.

This is a must read. Reading this guide is arming yourself with a tool kit to seek truth.Novella discusses an exhaustive amount of logical fallacies and fills the book in with historic examples of logical fallacies. If this book was required course material for every high schooler, we would likely live in a more sane and credible world instead of the abundance of fake news and other flimsy reporting we are forced to put up with. Just a fantastic and incredibly important read. Highly suggested material here.

I'm a fan of their podcast, but I felt it could have been shorter. I did pick up some good tidbits, but I must say the podcast is always better than the book. The title really should be: Where the Logic Fails in the Most Popular Myths. I wish it was more like Thinking Fast and Slow in that they don't require a prerequisite of believing in evolution and the Big Bang to buy into the narrative. For the GMO debate: What about the use of pesticides in traditional vs. organic crops? Or the amount of co2 released for every pound of a traditional crop vs. organic?

We are all struggling through this complex universe just like everyone who came before us.This book is a great whirlwind tour of human reasoning deficiencies (citing psychological studies that demonstrate them) and logical fallacies. It also provides some useful introductory information on concrete controversial topics like GMO foods and naturopathy.I particularly appreciated the effort to give specific content to the idea of “denialism” beyond just “disagreeing with the consensus,” and the recognition that science and pseudoscience fall along a continuum.

I've been a listener to the Skeptics' Guide to the Universe podcast for a long time now, so I was really looking forward to this book. It didn't disappoint. It goes through a bunch of ways our brain can be fooled, sloppy thinking and how to minimize it, and some case studies about using these techniques in practice. I found it very useful. It's almost like a reference in some sense. Reading it straight through is definitely good, but I imagine I'll look through it quite a few more times here and there. It's a great introduction to critical thinking.

Good intro book on skepticism. I was familiar with the topic having been an SGU podcast listener many many years ago so I was primed on the topic.Format of the book seems like vignettes from the podcast, a good reference book. Very easy to read and not overly clinical (if at all). I appreciate this format as I expect it will be easier to look for refreshers.Not sure which bias prevented me from clicking the fifth star on the review. I may tweak it up one more if I find myself going back to it.

A very long but enjoyable book, for most it's probably best to read sort of as a reference book rather than from start to end, though it works well even with that. Goes over the topic of scientific skepticism and critical thinking in great detail and was a very interesting book to read as someone who has relatively recently been introduced to the podcast. It might have been a bit nice if there was a demarcation of the different hosts, since without there being outside of the adventures in Skepticism it made me feel as though it was mostly Steven Novella writing it.

If I could recommend any “essential must reads” this year, this book would at the top of the list. Steven Novella takes us on a journey across the human psyche and debunks common tropes, popular conspiracies, personal biases, and the “pseudoscientific method”. Novella does a fantastic job in presenting the logical fallacies we too often commit because of our incorrect memories, personal beliefs, and experiences. What is important is being aware of those biases and open to continuously question all information.

I overall enjoyed this audiobook. It was engaging to listen to, but the encyclopedia format wasn't the best in audio. This would be a great coffee table book as you could flip through and refer back to small sections if you wanted. It was nice to consume in small bite-sized chunks, but it wasn't something I was itching to listen to more. The information is solid with entertaining and useful examples. Overall, it was a good review of a lot of cognitive biases that we have and I found myself remembering times I've used these types of arguments in conversations (and when they were used on me). It was a good reminder to provide more thoughtful arguments when debating other people.

I do love that this book exists! I have to admit that I am a listener to SGU and thus my opinions will be biased partly from that. I do like the book a lot! It is a very comprehensive guide to skepticism that condenses lots of experiances from a group of well trained skeptics! It is an interesting read but I would have loved the book to be written in a way so that it would hook me a bit more. Now I liked the info but I did feel like it could have been written in a more ”exciting” way. I am looking forward to the next book from Steve and the gang.

This is definitely an important piece of work for the times we live in. The books explains many faulty thinking traps that we often find ourselves in as well as the basics of logical argumentation. One specific character in the book lives in LA (of all places) and is named “Aubrey” but I will forgive the authors for this. It’s obviously too fantastic to believe...😝. Anyways, read this book and get yourself educated. It’s difficult not to lose your sense of wonder about things after reading it. (Dreamers you have been warned)

Highly recommended for anyone who: can't fathom why some people believe things that defy logic and fact; want to compile strategies for counteracting magical thinking, misinformation, fake news, and the like; want to ensure that their own thinking is divorced of unprovable fact. 4/5 stars means I really liked this book and would strongly recommend it.This books deals with scientific skepticism; a subject which has very little recognition among society at large, but which I consider extremely important.The author ventures to build a well-organised overview of the subject, and I think he succeeds at it to a good degree. Having said that, I would very much like for the book to be even more rigorous, more detailed and better cited. In short, I would like it to be a bit more on the rigorous/academic side and less on the simplified/"popularised"/dumbed-down side.One thing I would consider a minor flaw is that objective fact and the authors' opinion is not always 100% clear (thus why I would want for the book to be better cited). The clearest example of this is the short discussion on the hard problem of consciousness, where the author presents Dennett's view as the obvious solution to the problem when most thinkers and scientists working in this field disagree with it.Lastly, the first few chapters of the book are really not that well-written (I tried reading the book twice and twice I quit at the very beginning because I found it very uninteresting) but once you are past page 40 or so it becomes much easier to read. It's really worth muscling your way though those first pages because the information on this book is really important.I think that this book nicely complements Kahneman's "Thinking Fast and Slow", offering additional tools to improve one's thinking process.

Heuristics: A form of cognitive bias. Pseudosciences of today have their roots in the past. At least, pessimism was ranked higher that positive thinking, although I always considered pessimism to be realistic thinking. Guess what? The future is hard to predict.  Perhaps, the bottom line is that many people/groups believe many things perhaps because they can or perhaps because that is what they taught. Or, perhaps the things are in their best fiscal interest. There are plenty of words in this volume. A lot of ink was killed to print this book.  Maybe the message is: don’t believe nothing until you have checked it out.... and, then, check it out again. Or maybe it has something to do with too many anecdotes. If it is not one goofiness, it is another- to paraphrase my mother. Finally, after all the anecdotes, chapter 56 (Being Skeptical) gets down to business. So, do not give up before at least reading these few pages.  Critical thinking is part of being real. Most people are not real. Perhaps, they should read this book.

We are all brought into this world as children ready to believe anything, we make connections, notice all the hits and fail to observe the many more misses (how astrology requires and needs it as do psychics). It takes something like science to understand the truth, but it’s up against a range of bias and glitches already in our thinking. These include glitches such as cognitive biases (searching and noticing only evidence that supports the beliefs you’ve already formed) and the Dunning–Kruger effect whereby people believe they are better than others but actually lack so much self-awareness to don’t realise how little they truly know. Think Trump perhaps. This book explains so much of magical thinking, the type where intelligent people can be just as foolish and ignorant in their thinking as anyone else because what is sometimes more important is the ability to use critical thinking as opposed to magical thinking. This book beautifully demonstrates our biases and glitches in our thinking including memory (memory can be easily distorted) and how we delude ourselves. This is an excellent book for helping you to become more aware and to overcome all your biases and to look at more appropriate ways of thinking, Particularly through the use of science. Fools and fanatics are certain of everything but to be wise in your thinking means you have to question everything, keep an open mind, be humble, uncertain and be doubtful, and question what you think you already know. This book will help you. I have read quite a bit on the subject so not all of this was new to me, but I’m sure it will be new to many.

In a new world dominated by untruth, social media and conspiracy theories being naturally skeptical and learning how to think critically has only grown in importance. Lucky for me I am a natural skeptic and do not often accept things at face value. For the more gullible individuals out there I would definitely recommend The Skeptics Guide to the Universe. Even for those people whom need multiple layers of evidence before they are convinced something is fact, it is a fun read.The skill of thinking critically and understanding what is real and what is not is becoming so important with the power of social media. Society is being flooded with falsehoods at such a fast rate because digital content reaches the masses like never before in our history. How can expect to spot all the fake stories on Twitter or Facebook if we cannot think critically? The purveyors of these falsehoods are relying on the fact that most people will not be able to pick out the truth. Books like The Skeptics Guide can train people to recognize the plentiful lies out there.The book is in no way a bore and the author, Dr. Steven Novella, keeps a nice flow with short chapters and providing real life examples for each of his skepticism techniques. If you are not normally an academic reader, but are looking for something in the realm of science that has practical applications then this could be the book for you. Don’t be a patsy and fall for the lies, pseudoscience, or fraud the world (or our own government) throws at you. Think about it critically and use the steps Dr. Novella provides to be better. No one wants to be a sheep so stand up, read this book, and lead the heard.

An exploration of skepticism that is engaging, thorough, and fun to read. I've been a fan of the eponymous podcast for years, and Novella does a good job of distilling the themes that are scattered throughout the hundreds of episodes and his blog. Highly recommended, either for long-time fans of the podcast and veterans of skepticism or for those exploring either for the first time.

Just as the title suggests, this is the perfect book for people who require some level of science-based, verifiable evidence before believing or promoting an idea. This is especially important in the age of the internet where numerous baseless theories are promoted on a daily basis. The book takes a deep-dive into the topics such as: science vs pseudoscience; conspiracy theories and why people love them; placebo effects; cherry-picking data; "moving the goalposts"; confirmation bias; and why science doesn't deal with faith-based issues, since science only deals with things that can be (at least hypothetically) disproved. Though there are a couple of chapters that get a bit dense, most of the chapters are quite easy to read and to grasp the main points of. What you realize by reading the book is that being called a skeptic is actually a badge of honor. We've seen what can result from hysterical thinking derived from theories that lacked of solid evidence; whether it be from the anti-vaxxers, to climate-change ignorers, to the witch-hunt trials in the 17th Century. The skeptic is the person who demands strong evidence and believes that a sound scientific model and expert consensus is the best way to separate fact from fiction.

I have been a skeptic for several years and am also a listener to the SGU-podcast. I recognize most of the topics discussed in the book, some have been discussed many times on the show.Still I enjoyed the book very much and read it rather quickly. Of course you don't have to be a seasoned skeptic to enjoy the book. I even envy readers wo read about this stuff for the first time. You should be aware that this is not just one of those self-help books that gives you simple recipes.This book really covers a lot of topics, it's astounding how many aspects skepticism has. Some chapters I want to praise especially are those about the workings of science, what shortages it has, especially when it comes to communicating the results. And the problems with science journalism. I simply cannot give it less than 5/5

🌈 As a fan of the podcast I can say that this is an entertaining and important book as both a companion and standalone work. I think there's a perception that science and skepticism don't really promote quality of life because they do not encourage happiness, connection, or introspection. This book as well as the "Skeptic's Guide to the Universe" podcast challenge that. The pursuit of objectivity and truth is profound in part because it is deeply moral. It is humble, unselfish, and honest. We cannot accept something as real simply because it suits a certain aesthetic or worldview or because we want it to be true. A belief that affects how we treat people (and I mean this medically and interpersonally) must be based upon honesty and evidence. Science is the elegant and essential process by which we gather that evidence.

This book has proven to be the beginning of a new endeavor to understand the world for me. It has proven to be the end of the way I used to view the world.Hard to describe how much of a burden has been lifted off my shoulders by relearning concepts that I had been taught once before but with baggage attached.This quote pretty much sums it up for me:“Skepticism is also fun and empowering. One of the most common bits of feedback we get from listeners is that they’ve finally shed a belief system, and how liberating it is. They don’t have to labor under an oppressive belief anymore. They can think freely and only believe what actually makes sense to them.”

Biased, preachy, repetitiveThe author presents the content textbook. That’s fine. There’s some good info presented but it is hidden in the repetition, political/belief bias, and contradicting ideas (ie. not practicing what you preach). There are a lot of “facts” presented without sources. He also chooses general arguments that exist in society and uses the most radical beliefs on the spectrum to breakdown. There is skepticism for the sake of truth (and sanity) and there is skepticism for the sake of pulling others down with the ship of misery. This book walks the fine line between them.

LOVED this book! Really got me thinking and questioning things. An in depth explanation of how conspiracy theories manifest, grow, & are believed. Really made me look at the individual who believed in these conspiracies as more of a victim than anything else & taught me how to think critically about information. Though I will still be holding onto my belief that there is life outside our solar system.

For a great reading and as a great referenceRefreshing reading particular during these times of quarantine and lot of news and rumors on the virus. Good to put in check any information. I loved also the tone, more if you are a fan of their podcast. As a practical guide to understand your own limitations, how to review any opinion you have and a list of dangerous pseudoscience beliefs. You can read in one go, and also as a reference of logical fallacies and more.

This is a great compendium of skeptical position papers on various subjects. Unlike a lot of books written by skeptics, you will come away from this knowing both the skeptic argument and the believer's argument very well. Most importantly, the book will force you to take a good long look at your own presuppositions and reasoning. Well worth the time spent.

A nice concise collection of many of the more important concepts regularly covered in the podcast. I'm handing it off to my girlfriend to read so she doesn't have to listen to over 600 episodes to get caught up.

I have read many similar books, on critical thinking, skepticism, epistemology... This is certainly the best of them all - if you are deciding between this book and something else, this is the book to choose.

This is a fantastic book on critical thinking. I especially enjoyed the explanation of the difference between skepticism and cynicism. I learned a lot about my own thinking patterns by reading this book and also learned a lot about how to reason better than I already do.
Very well done. Though much of this information is old hat for me, it's always good to review and of course gain new insights.
Awsome book
Absolutely essential guide to truth seeking via the best method known to humanity: scientific inquiry.
Excellent skeptical thinking about science. The problem with this is it doesn't have any clue about political science.

---- Disclosure: I received this book for free from Goodreads. ----  As someone w/ a degree in the hard sciences, I was not unfamiliar w/ the concepts & a fair bit of the material discussed in this book, but still found it to be quite a good read. It was a solid reminder of why vigilance in the scientific method & peer review process is so crucial. For non-scientist types, there will obviously be a lot in here to take under consideration. It would be a good overall primer to the very broad field of what "science" is, as well as what it most certainly is not.     There is a chunk near the front bit of the book that goes into a needed review of concepts like logical fallacies, & poor &/or specious arguments. This bit, quite honestly, can be a little tedious, but hang in there. It is necessary ground for dissecting what are good & proper statements of plausibility, & what stuff is just misleading crap, intentional or otherwise. Even outside the world of science, the knowledge of such things is invaluable. (Try practicing the evaluation of political statements & comments according to these concepts. It'll do your head in.)   I love that the book was a collaboration, with different people taking on different topics. They know of what they speak, & it shows. My only moment of confusion came w/ the Wason Selection Task, so I went online to seek out other sources. I found an explanation that was more preferable to me at http://skepdic.com/refuge/ctlessons/l... , but honestly it only made sense after I further read the current page at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wason_s... (I know, it's Wikipedia, but replacing the letter options with colors really helped my brain sort the information better.) I look forward to listening to the show sometime, as I knew nothing about it prior to this book. It sounds like it's my kind of thing. I also had a ton of fun over at http://www.tylervigen.com/spurious-co... , so thanks for bringing that into my life. Mostly though, I feel relieved to know there are real-life unrecognized superheroes such as these authors out there in the world. Every day they're out there somewhere, doing their good works, just because that's what they do. Seriously, that kind of thing is so under-valued, but ripples out into the world in ways that can not be measured.  I will surely recommend this book to others....well, to everyone, really. They'll have to get their own copies, though. I'm keeping mine so I can refer to the aforementioned section on various false arguments & unsound premises. I can usually recognize such things, but I have a hard time remembering exactly which b.s./problem elements are related to which kind of erroneous of statements or thought processes, if that makes any sense. Regardless, I'm keeping the book on my shelf, so thanks!  P.S.: The section on GMO's I had trepidation about entering, but you handled it like a champ. Very well done, indeed.
